MKT.name: Market Magnitude
MKT.description: Realistic capturable market in 3-5 years. Not hand-waving TAM but plausible revenue ceiling for a single company.

scale.9-10: $10B+ addressable, platform-scale outcome (log-scale, top quartile only)

CAP.name: Capture Feasibility
CAP.description: Can a seed-funded startup realistically capture meaningful share in 3-5 years? Measures actual capture mechanics, not hype.

scale.1-2: Incumbents own distribution, 24+ month sales cycles, regulatory blocks
scale.5-6: Mixed channels, some accessible, 6-12 month sales cycles
scale.7-8: Direct acquisition viable, PLG possible, 3-6 month cycles
scale.9-10: Greenfield with pull demand, viral/PLG, customers actively seeking

ECO.name: Unit Economics
ECO.description: Steady-state margin and capital efficiency. Architecture-driven — maps business model to known margin profile.

scale.5-6: Mixed model, 45-60% gross margins, some recurring revenue
scale.7-8: Software/SaaS, 65-80% gross margins, strong unit economics
scale.9-10: Pure software/data, 80%+ margins, near-zero marginal cost

VEL.name: Revenue Velocity
VEL.description: Speed from $0 to $5M ARR. Determines whether 3-5 year window produces markable outcome.

scale.1-2: 36+ months to first material revenue, deep-tech R&D
scale.3-4: 18-36 months, long enterprise sales or regulatory approvals
scale.5-6: 12-18 months, standard B2B SaaS sales cycle
scale.9-10: <6 months, viral/PLG with instant activation, pull demand

MOA.name: Moat Trajectory
MOA.description: Once you have traction, does the business get harder or easier to compete with? Measures 5-year defensibility arc.

scale.1-2: Commodity forever, anyone can replicate, no switching costs
scale.3-4: Moderate switching costs, relationship moat only
scale.5-6: Meaningful switching costs + some data effects, but displaceable
scale.7-8: Strong compounding moat — data flywheel, regulatory capture, multi-product lock-in
scale.9-10: Winner-take-most dynamics, data moat grows exponentially

models.name: Retail Media Network Platform
models.one_liner: Advertising platform built on retailer first-party data, transforming retail from margin business to media business. $69.3B market in 2026, growing 20% annually. Amazon (77% share) + Walmart Connect ($4.4B) dominate.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Retail footprint contraction accelerates beyond AI-optimization ability to offset
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Amazon controls 77% of retail media ($56B). First-party purchase data + retailer exclusivity = near-unbreakable moat. Enabling tech layer (Criteo, CitrusAd, Kevel) exists but is thin and commoditizable. Google Ads could aggregate mid-market but doesn't solve the retailer-owned data problem. Entry limited to ad-tech tools, not the network itself. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [54.0 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Retail media $69B+ but Amazon controls 77%. Massive market, near-impossible capture at seed stage.
models.deep_dive_evidence: US retail media spending: $58.8B (2025) to $69.3B (2026), growing 20%/year. Amazon Ads at $56B, 77% market share. Walmart Connect $4.4B, up 27% YoY, +53% globally with Vizio acquisition. Retail media fundamentally changes retail economics: stores and logistics operate at near break-even, advertising generates profit margin. This is why Amazon can undercut on price -- they monetize traffic, not products. Mid-market retailers building their own networks (Kroger Precision Marketing, Target Roundel).

models.name: Climate Risk Analytics and Disclosure Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered climate risk modeling, scenario analysis, and regulatory disclosure platform for corporates and financial institutions — serving mandatory SEC and EU CSRD reporting requirements across 50,000+ affected companies
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Finance and Insurance successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=data_compounding, NAICS=52, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: The SEC's climate disclosure rule (adopted March 2024, partially stayed pending litigation but Scope 1/2 reporting proceeding) requires public companies to report greenhouse gas emissions, climate risk governance, and transition plans. The EU's CSRD is more aggressive — requiring 50,000+ companies (including non-EU companies with significant EU revenue) to report under European Sustainability Reporting Standards (ESRS) starting 2024-2026 in phases. Together, these mandates create a structural requirement for climate risk analytics that did not exist 3 years ago. The climate risk analytics market is projected at $4.8B by 2029 (MarketsandMarkets, 22.3% CAGR). Current landscape: Persefoni (raised $101M) provides carbon accounting for SEC/CSRD compliance. Watershed (raised $100M, valued at $1.8B) serves enterprise carbon management. S&P Global, MSCI, and Moody's offer climate risk scoring but lack the granular physical risk modeling and disclosure automation that corporates need. The data moat opportunity: climate risk modeling requires integrating satellite imagery, weather data, supply chain mapping, emissions factors, and financial data into company-specific risk scores. Each client engagement generates proprietary risk data that improves models. Banks and insurers need portfolio-level climate risk aggregation for TCFD/ECB stress testing — JPMorgan alone has $3.4T in assets requiring climate risk assessment. The gap between regulatory requirement and corporate capability is enormous: Deloitte's 2025 climate survey found only 23% of affected companies have automated climate data collection, and 68% are relying on spreadsheets for CSRD reporting.

models.name: Post-Quantum Cryptography Migration Platform
models.one_liner: Enterprise migration platform for NIST post-quantum cryptographic standards — automated PKI inventory, cipher suite replacement, and compliance validation targeting the $3.2B PQC migration market by 2030 as harvest-now-decrypt-later threats accelerate government and financial sector deadlines
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Information successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=vertical_saas, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: NIST finalized three post-quantum cryptographic standards in August 2024 (FIPS 203 ML-KEM, FIPS 204 ML-DSA, FIPS 205 SLH-DSA), triggering the largest cryptographic migration since the SHA-1 to SHA-2 transition. The NSA's CNSA 2.0 timeline mandates PQC adoption for all national security systems by 2030, with software and firmware signing required by 2025. The harvest-now-decrypt-later threat — adversaries capturing encrypted data today to decrypt with future quantum computers — makes the timeline urgent for financial services, healthcare, and government. MarketsandMarkets projects the PQC market reaching $3.2B by 2030 from $310M in 2024 (43% CAGR). The core problem is discovery: large enterprises have 50,000-500,000+ cryptographic assets (certificates, keys, cipher suites) embedded across applications, APIs, and infrastructure with no centralized inventory. IBM, Thales, and Entrust are offering PQC toolkits but none provide automated end-to-end migration orchestration. SandboxAQ (spun out of Alphabet) raised $500M and is targeting this space. Estimated 85% of Fortune 500 companies have not begun PQC readiness assessment (Deloitte 2025 survey). Federal contractors face binding deadlines under OMB M-23-02 requiring cryptographic inventory by 2025 and migration plans by 2026.

models.name: AI Governance and Compliance Operating System
models.one_liner: Enterprise platform managing AI model inventory, risk assessment, bias monitoring, and regulatory compliance across US/EU/China regimes.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Consumer and enterprise AI trust rises above 70% (Edelman), eliminating fear-friction demand
models.cla_rationale: Market is nascent ($309M→$15.8B projected, 51x). No dominant AI-native governance platform exists. Legacy compliance tools (ServiceNow, IBM) haven't pivoted to AI governance. Three diverging regulatory regimes (US/EU/China) prevent single-winner dynamics and reward specialized expertise. EU AI Act deadline (Aug 2026) is a hard forcing function. Fear-driven demand (46% adoption plateau) CREATES market rather than just filling it.
models.vcr_rationale: AI governance platform. Enterprise compliance, growing regulatory push, but immature buying process.

models.name: Warehouse Fulfillment Robotics Platform
models.one_liner: End-to-end warehouse automation (goods-to-person robots, automated sorting, AI pick-path optimization) for retail fulfillment centers. $181B market by 2031 at 31.6% CAGR.
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
General merchandise retail consolidates to 3-4 dominant players, locking out new technology vendors
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Amazon Robotics (ex-Kiva) and Symbotic (Walmart) dominate. Capital + IP + installation lock-in form hard moats. Multi-layer stack (hardware AMR/AGV, pick-path AI, integration, maintenance) provides entry points. Humanoid robotics (Unitree, AgiBot, Figure) is a real disruption vector but 3-5 years from warehouse deployment. Open-source robot brains (Alibaba RynnBrain VLA) could democratize software layer. DECOMPOSED: 3 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE, CONTESTED. OPP range [50.5 — 66.5]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Warehouse robotics $181B by 2031 but requires massive capex. Hardware margins. Not seed-fundable at core.
models.deep_dive_evidence: Retail robotics growing from $20.1B (2024) to $181.1B (2031) at 31.6% CAGR. Symbotic acquired Walmart's Advanced Systems division for $200M. Humanoid robotics funding up 300% (v38-S40). AMR/AGV market $13.2B by 2026. NVIDIA Jetson T4000 ($1,999) makes robot compute cheaper than smartphones. Alibaba open-sourced RynnBrain VLA model (v38-S06). Physical AI is the next major platform after software AI.

models.name: Autonomous Drone Swarm Command Platform

falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Reshoring momentum reverses as tariff policy changes eliminate onshoring economic rationale
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Defense procurement barriers, security clearances, ITAR restrictions severely limit entry. Anduril, Shield AI, L3Harris dominate. Classified tech and government relationships are hard moats. Commercial drone tech is cheaper and evolving faster — Ukraine conflict proves smaller companies can compete. AUKUS opens allied markets. Best entry through NATO allies or specific subsystems.
models.vcr_rationale: Autonomous drone swarms. Massive defense TAM but procurement barriers kill seed-stage capture.

models.name: Cybersecurity AI for Defense Networks
models.one_liner: AI-powered network defense and threat hunting platform purpose-built for CMMC 2.0 compliance across the 300K+ Defense Industrial Base.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Cyber market broadly is crowded (CrowdStrike, Palo Alto dominate enterprise). But defense-specific AI-native cybersecurity is less crowded. CMMC certification creates barrier-as-moat. Expanding attack surface + AI-generated attacks require AI defense. Defense budgets growing.
models.vcr_rationale: Defense cybersecurity. Big TAM but procurement kills velocity and capture.

models.name: AI Jobsite Safety Monitoring Platform
models.one_liner: Computer vision + wearable IoT platform that detects safety hazards in real-time (fall risk, PPE compliance, struck-by exposure) on construction jobsites -- addressing the $4.6B construction worker safety market by 2030 within the broader $24.3B AI in construction market
falsification_criteria: Open-source or foundation model alternatives eliminate proprietary data moat advantages
Data privacy regulations (state-level CCPA variants) restrict data aggregation business model
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Construction safety is the strongest demand signal in contech -- OSHA fines doubled in 2023, EMR (experience modification rate) directly impacts insurance premiums and bidding eligibility. Newmetrix (acquired by Oracle 2023) and Smartvid.io (acquired by Newmetrix) validated the category. Current leaders include Versatile (crane monitoring), Triax (wearables), and various startups. Market openness is moderate-high because no single platform dominates across all safety vectors (fall protection, struck-by, PPE, housekeeping, trenching). Oracle/Newmetrix is enterprise-focused. The mid-market (200K+ firms) is largely unserved. Demand visibility is the highest of any construction AI category: every GC faces OSHA compliance, insurance pressure, and moral obligation.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=predictive_analytics, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $24300M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction is the deadliest major industry: 1,056 fatalities in 2023 (BLS), 200K+ non-fatal injuries. OSHA's 'Fatal Four' (falls 33.5%, struck-by 11.1%, electrocution 7.0%, caught-in/between 5.4%) are all detectable by computer vision. OSHA maximum penalties increased to $16,131 per serious violation and $161,323 per willful violation (2024 adjustment). The construction worker safety market: $3.2B (2024) to $4.6B (2030) at 6.0% CAGR (GlobeNewswire/ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific safety solutions growing at 30.5% CAGR within this market (Grand View Research). Insurance incentive: a single fatality costs $5M+ in direct costs; EMR impacts persist for 3 years on all bids. AI safety platforms (camera-based + wearable) can reduce recordable incidents 40-60% based on pilot data from Newmetrix, Smartvid.io, and Suffolk Construction deployments. Pricing: $2-5K/month per active jobsite for camera-based monitoring, $5-15/month per wearable per worker.

models.name: Infrastructure Inspection AI & Drone Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered drone and sensor platform for bridge, road, and utility infrastructure inspection -- replacing dangerous manual inspections in the $38.2B drone inspection market by 2030, with the US infrastructure backlog creating $2.6T in needed repairs (ASCE)
falsification_criteria: Robotics hardware costs remain above adoption threshold for target customer segment
Regulatory approval for autonomous operation takes 3+ years longer than projected
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Infrastructure inspection is the strongest convergence point in construction: (1) IIJA mandates inspection of 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges, (2) manual inspection is dangerous (inspector fatalities, lane closures causing accidents), (3) inspector workforce is aging and shrinking, (4) drone + AI technology is mature enough for deployment. Current players: DroneUp, Skydio (raised $750M, US-made drones for defense/infrastructure), Flyability (confined space), Gecko Robotics (wall-climbing robots for utilities), and various DOT-specific solutions. Market openness is moderate: Skydio dominates the hardware layer for US government use (Chinese drone ban benefits US manufacturers). The AI ANALYSIS layer (identifying cracks, corrosion, deformation from drone imagery) is where the value concentrates and where competition is fragmented. Demand visibility is extreme: $2.6T infrastructure backlog (ASCE 2025 Report Card) + IIJA spending mandate.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=autonomous_systems, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $2600000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US infrastructure condition: ASCE 2025 Infrastructure Report Card grades US infrastructure C- overall, with $2.6T investment gap. 45,000+ structurally deficient bridges (7.5% of total). 40% of roads in poor or mediocre condition. 7,500 dam safety deficiencies. IIJA: $110B for roads and bridges, $55B for water, $65B for broadband -- all requiring inspection capacity. Current manual bridge inspection: $5-25K per bridge, requires lane closures (costing $50K+/day in economic impact), and exposes inspectors to fall risk. Drone inspection: $1-5K per bridge, no lane closure, higher-resolution data capture. Global drone inspection and monitoring market: $16.4B (2024) to $38.2B (2030) at 15.1% CAGR (ResearchAndMarkets). AI-specific drone analysis: $821M (2025) to $2.75B (2030) at 27.4% CAGR. The FAA BVLOS (beyond visual line of sight) waiver program is expanding, enabling autonomous long-range inspections. Skydio's $750M raise and US government contracts validate the hardware layer. The AI layer (automated crack detection, corrosion measurement, structural deformation analysis) is where the most defensible value lies -- each inspection adds training data that improves detection accuracy.

models.name: Defense AI/ML Intelligence Fusion Platform
models.one_liner: Multi-source intelligence fusion using LLMs to synthesize SIGINT/HUMINT/OSINT/GEOINT into actionable briefs at 100x analyst throughput.
falsification_criteria: Cloud hyperscalers (AWS/Azure/GCP) build equivalent infrastructure as native features
Market fragments into point solutions rather than consolidating onto platforms
Professional licensing bodies restrict AI-assisted service delivery in regulated professions
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

Palantir's data moat + classified environment access = very strong moats. Only entry is through very specific niches (tactical-edge fusion for small units) or allied nations. Open-source LLMs could democratize some fusion but classified data handling limits this severely. DECOMPOSED: 1 sub-models spanning ACCESSIBLE. OPP range [61.0 — 61.0]. See sub-models for layer-specific entry analysis.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform, buyer=multi, frag=7, tam_source=sector $1200000M→$12000M addressable, defense penalty

models.name: AI-Native Restaurant Operating System
models.one_liner: Unified AI-powered back-office platform for independent restaurants — scheduling, inventory, accounting, vendor management in one system targeting the $14.7B restaurant management software market by 2030
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment
Minimum wage increases compress restaurant margins beyond AI savings capacity
Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Toast dominates restaurant tech at 120K+ locations but charges $69-$165/mo per terminal plus payment processing — leaving massive room for AI-native challengers that compress multiple point solutions. Market Openness is moderate (6): Toast, Square, Clover have distribution but independents remain deeply underserved (only 38% use digital ordering). Moat Advantage is strong (7): data compounding across scheduling, inventory, and accounting creates switching costs once embedded — the restaurant OS becomes the system of record. Value Density is moderate (5): $200-400/mo ARPU from small restaurants with high churn (56-day avg employee tenure mirrors owner turnover). Demand Visibility is proven (9): 611K restaurants with <$3K/year tech spend is the most visible unmet demand in any sector. The gap between chain sophistication and independent capability is the largest technology adoption gap in the US economy.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, buyer=smb_mid, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $14700M
models.deep_dive_evidence: QCEW data confirms 610,970 restaurant and eating places establishments (NAICS 7225) employing 10.95M workers at $502/week ($26,097 annual) — a Baumol score of 0.36, the lowest in the economy. Grand View Research projects the restaurant management software market reaching $14.7B by 2030 from $5.79B in 2024 (17.4% CAGR). The core thesis: independent restaurants (90%+ of establishments) spend less than $3,000/year on technology versus chains spending $15,000-50,000+/year per location. This $12-47K gap per location across 550K+ independents represents a $6.6-25.8B annual technology spend gap. Toast proved the category ($1.2B+ revenue) but charges payment processing spreads on top of SaaS fees — the AI-native entrant can offer a unified OS (scheduling via AI demand prediction, inventory via computer vision waste tracking, accounting via transaction auto-categorization, vendor management via price comparison) at lower total cost by monetizing the software layer rather than payment spreads. The 2022-2023 QCEW data shows establishments growing 2.5% YoY while employment grows 3.5% — new restaurants are opening and hiring, validating continued demand. Average workers per establishment of 17.9 means the buyer is a small-business owner who needs simplicity, not enterprise features.

models.name: EU AI Act Compliance Automation Engine
models.one_liner: Automated compliance platform that continuously monitors AI systems against EU AI Act's risk-based requirements -- going beyond V3-GEO-004's advisory model to embed compliance-as-code into AI deployment pipelines for the 450M-person EU market
models.sector_name: Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Software Publishers — EU AI Regulatory Compliance successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=compliance_automation, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: EU AI Act: entered force Feb 2025, prohibited AI practices banned immediately, high-risk system requirements phased in through 2027. Fines up to 7% of global revenue for non-compliance (vs GDPR's 4%). Every company deploying AI in EU needs: (1) risk classification per system, (2) conformity assessment for high-risk, (3) transparency documentation, (4) human oversight protocols, (5) continuous monitoring for performance drift and bias. Current compliance is manual (legal teams + consultants at $500-1000/hour). Automated compliance-as-code could reduce cost 80-90%. TAM: every company deploying AI in EU = potentially 100K+ organizations in first 3 years. SOC 2 compliance automation precedent: Vanta reached $2.5B valuation automating a much simpler compliance requirement. EU AI Act compliance is 10x more complex than SOC 2. Revenue model: SaaS per AI system monitored ($500-5000/month per system, depending on risk tier).

models.name: Skilled Trades Workforce Marketplace & Upskilling Platform
models.one_liner: Two-sided marketplace connecting 2M+ specialty trade workers with 540K contractor firms, with embedded skills verification, credential management, and AR-powered upskilling -- addressing the 650K worker shortage in a $130B temporary staffing market where 17.2% of gig workers are in construction
falsification_criteria: Supply-side participants disintermediate the platform through direct relationships
Network effects fail to materialize due to low transaction frequency in the sector
Construction labor shortage resolves through immigration reform, reducing automation urgency
Immigration policy reversal fills labor gaps, reducing demographic pressure on automation
models.cla_rationale: No dominant digital marketplace exists for construction labor. Current solutions: (1) Traditional staffing agencies (Tradesmen International, $1.5B+ revenue; PeopleReady) -- high-fee, low-tech. (2) Workrise (formerly RigUp, $500M+ raised) -- primarily oil & gas, expanding to construction. (3) Instawork, Wonolo -- general gig, not construction-specific. (4) Hireup (construction-focused, early). The gap is a construction-native platform with: credential verification (licenses, OSHA cards, drug tests), skill-matching (an electrician is not a plumber), project-based scheduling (not gig-by-gig), and embedded upskilling (AR training for new certifications). Market openness is high because traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup and the 'Uber for construction workers' has not been built. Demand visibility is the highest possible: 650K unfilled positions is not a forecast, it is a measured gap.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=marketplace, buyer=multi, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $130000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction workforce crisis by the numbers: 650K+ unfilled positions (Feb 2026 estimate based on AGC survey + BLS JOLTS data). 77% of firms report difficulty filling hourly craft positions (AGC 2025 Workforce Survey). Average construction worker age 42.5 and rising. Net annual deficit: ~100K workers/year (retirements exceed new entrants). 24% of construction workforce is foreign-born (Pew Research), concentrated in residential (30%+) -- directly exposed to immigration enforcement. Electrician shortage: 80K+ nationally (IBEW). HVAC technician shortage: 45K+. CSIS (Jan 2026): US needs 140K additional skilled trade workers by 2030 just for clean energy and data center construction. Traditional staffing agencies charge 30-50% markup; digital marketplace could reduce to 15-20% while improving matching speed from days to hours. Credential management is a massive pain point: the average specialty contractor carries 15-25 different licenses, certifications, and insurance documents that must be current for each project. An integrated marketplace with embedded credential verification, AI skill-matching, and AR upskilling modules creates a 3-sided platform (workers, contractors, training providers).

models.name: India Stack AI Application Factory

falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Software Publishers — India Digital Infrastructure successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: India GenAI startups: 890+ by H1 2025, 3.7x cumulative growth, 83% are application-layer (NASSCOM). India startup funding: $11B in 2025 (TechCrunch). Early-stage AI funding: $273M in 100 rounds. India Digital Public Infrastructure: Aadhaar (1.3B enrolled), UPI ($2T+ annual volume, 10B+ monthly transactions), ONDC (open commerce network). India is 'mobile-first economy' with decentralized startup ecosystem -- 50% of DPIIT-recognized startups from non-metro cities. Inc42: 2026-2027 is a 'high-leverage window for India's AI startups.' NITI Aayog report: AI could add $500B to India's GDP by 2025. The middleware layer (API gateway to India Stack for AI apps) is genuinely missing -- global AI companies struggle to integrate with India's unique identity/payments infrastructure.

Finance, ops, legal, customer service, project management — many layers for the AI OS. Every SaaS tool (QuickBooks, Salesforce) is a potential vector to build from, but none are building the integrated AI OS. Highest opportunity score in entire inventory.

models.name: AI-Optimized Liquid Cooling for Data Centers
models.one_liner: Intelligent direct-to-chip and immersion liquid cooling systems for AI data centers — replacing air cooling that cannot handle 120kW+ GPU racks, serving a $12.5B data center cooling market growing at 20% CAGR as AI compute density doubles annually
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Manufacturing — Electronics successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=hardware_ai, NAICS=33, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=hardware_ai, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: AI data center power density is outstripping air cooling physics. NVIDIA's Blackwell B200 GPU draws 1,000W per chip; a rack of 8 GPUs with networking and compute overhead reaches 100-150kW per rack — versus 15-25kW for traditional server racks. Air cooling physically cannot remove 100kW+ from a standard 42U rack without unacceptable airflow velocities and temperature differentials. This is not a preference — it is a thermodynamic constraint. The data center cooling market was $9.2B in 2024 and is projected to reach $25.5B by 2030 (Mordor Intelligence, 18.3% CAGR), with liquid cooling specifically reaching $12.5B. Three architectures compete: direct-to-chip (cold plates on CPUs/GPUs with liquid loops — deployed by CoolIT Systems at 4M+ nodes), rear-door heat exchangers (retrofit for existing racks), and full immersion (submerging servers in dielectric fluid — GRC, LiquidCool Solutions). Microsoft deployed liquid cooling across Azure AI data centers in 2024. Google uses liquid cooling for TPU pods. Meta is transitioning to liquid cooling for GPU clusters. NVIDIA mandates liquid cooling capability for Blackwell-based systems. The AI optimization layer is the differentiation: intelligent coolant flow control that adapts to GPU workload patterns (LLM inference has different thermal profiles than training), predictive maintenance using vibration and temperature sensors, and energy optimization that can reduce PUE from 1.3 (air) to 1.05-1.10 (liquid). CoolIT Systems (private, profitable) is the market leader in direct-to-chip but serves primarily hyperscalers — the enterprise and colocation segments remain underserved. Vertiv ($VRT, stock up 400%+ in 2024) and Schneider Electric are developing liquid cooling products but are not yet shipping at scale. The urgency is extreme: data center capacity is the binding constraint on AI scaling, and cooling is the binding constraint on density.

The patient management gap is stark: GLP-1 patients experience significant side effects (nausea in 44%, muscle loss of 25-40% of weight lost, gallbladder events in 1.5%), require dosing titration over 16-20 weeks, need nutritional guidance to preserve lean mass, and face indefinite treatment duration with high discontinuation rates (50-70% stop within 1 year per real-world data from Truveta). The opportunity: a SaaS platform sold to health systems, employer wellness programs, and GLP-1 manufacturers that tracks patient outcomes, optimizes dosing schedules using real-world evidence, integrates CGM and body composition data, and reduces the $15,000+/year drug cost through improved adherence and reduced adverse events. Digital health companies Calibrate and Found focus on prescribing, not outcomes management — the post-prescription journey is unserved.

models.name: Energy Code & Sustainability Compliance Platform for Construction
models.one_liner: AI platform automating energy code compliance, LEED/WELL certification documentation, and embodied carbon tracking for new construction -- targeting the $17.5B building code compliance market by 2032 where 70% of firms already use software for green certification and energy codes are tightening 15-25% per cycle

models.cla_rationale: Energy code compliance is increasingly mandatory and increasingly complex. Current tools: (1) EnergyPlus (DOE, free, complex), (2) REScheck/COMcheck (DOE, basic compliance), (3) IES VE, eQUEST (commercial energy modeling, $10K+/year), (4) Autodesk Insight (integrated with Revit but limited), (5) cove.tool ($30M raised, performance-based building design). No single platform connects energy code compliance to permit submission to sustainability certification to embodied carbon tracking. The fragmentation of energy codes across jurisdictions (some states on IECC 2021, others on 2024, California on Title 24) creates complexity that AI can simplify. 70% of firms in developed regions already use software for green building compliance -- the question is whether a new platform can consolidate the workflow. Demand visibility is high: every new building must comply with energy codes, and codes are tightening every 3 years.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Building sector consumes 40% of US energy. Building codes are the primary policy lever for reducing building energy consumption. IECC 2024 (adopted by 12 states as of Feb 2026) requires 15-25% energy improvement over 2021 baseline, including: mandatory blower door testing, continuous insulation, high-efficiency HVAC, and for commercial buildings, automated lighting controls and energy recovery ventilation. California Title 24 (2025 cycle) mandates all-electric new construction in many zones. NYC LL97 imposes carbon penalties on existing buildings >25,000 SF starting 2024 (up to $268/ton CO2). 9 states mandate heat pumps in new residential. Embodied carbon: Portland, Vancouver, and LEED v5 now require lifecycle carbon assessment of construction materials. Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR. Green building certification market growing at 11.2% CAGR. cove.tool ($30M raised) has proven the 'performance-based design' category. The integration opportunity: a single platform that (1) identifies applicable energy codes by jurisdiction, (2) runs automated energy modeling on building designs, (3) checks compliance and generates required documentation, (4) tracks embodied carbon in material selections, (5) generates LEED/WELL/ENERGY STAR documentation. For residential builders (1.1M workers, 225K firms), energy code compliance is the FASTEST-GROWING source of project complexity and delay.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The earth observation data and services market reached $6.1B in 2024 and is projected to hit $9.4B by 2028 (Euroconsult, 14% CAGR). Critically, the commercial segment now exceeds the defense/intelligence segment for the first time — agriculture, insurance, energy, finance, and infrastructure monitoring collectively represent 60%+ of demand. Planet Labs ($PL, ~$180M annual revenue) provides daily global 3m imagery from 200+ satellites but generates only basic analytics. The value gap: raw satellite imagery is abundant and commoditizing; AI-derived insights are scarce and high-value. Specific verticals demonstrate this: crop yield prediction (Descartes Labs, Gro Intelligence) commands $5-50/acre from commodity traders and insurers; infrastructure monitoring (Orbital Insight, HawkEye 360) charges $50-500K/year for pipeline and power line surveillance; deforestation monitoring commands $100K+ per engagement from ESG-mandated corporations. The analytics layer has better unit economics than the satellite layer — Planet Labs has -10% operating margins despite $180M revenue, while analytics providers operate at 60-80% gross margins with no space hardware risk. The data compounding advantage: AI models trained on multi-year, multi-spectral satellite archives with ground-truth validation (actual crop yields, confirmed insurance claims, verified deforestation) improve continuously. SAR (synthetic aperture radar) data from Capella Space and ICEYE adds all-weather, day-night capability. The CHIPS Act and ITAR reform are enabling US commercial earth observation exports that were previously restricted. Maxar's $6.4B acquisition by Advent International (2023) validates category value at the asset level.

Demand Visibility is proven (9): hospitality has the highest quit rate of any sector (5.7% monthly in food services per BLS JOLTS) — workforce management is a survival requirement, not a nice-to-have.

The scheduling software market was valued at $1.46B in 2025 (360iResearch) growing at 7.9% CAGR. But the real opportunity is workforce intelligence — not just scheduling but predictive demand-based staffing (AI analyzes weather, events, holidays, historical patterns to predict covers and staff accordingly), automated compliance (tip credit tracking, predictive scheduling laws in NYC/SF/Chicago/Seattle, break compliance, overtime management), and retention analytics (identifying which employees are at risk of quitting based on schedule satisfaction, hours stability, and peer patterns). The regulatory tailwind is significant: predictive scheduling laws now cover 10M+ workers and are expanding. The total workforce management value opportunity for hospitality: scheduling ($1.5B), compliance ($800M), hiring/retention ($600M), tip management ($400M) = $3.3B addressable by 2028.

models.deep_dive_evidence: The global workforce management market is growing from $8.4B in 2025 to $13.0B by 2030 at 9.2% CAGR (MarketsandMarkets). The US has 80M+ hourly workers (BLS), representing 55% of the workforce. NAICS 56 directly employs 9.4M of these workers and places millions more through staffing agencies. The compliance landscape is increasingly complex: predictive scheduling laws (requiring advance notice of schedules, penalty pay for changes) now exist in 12+ jurisdictions with more pending. Fair workweek legislation, minimum wage variation across 50+ state/local jurisdictions, break and meal period rules, and overtime calculations create a compliance minefield. Wage theft claims exceed $15B annually (Economic Policy Institute), with scheduling violations a growing category. Immigration enforcement is intensifying: E-Verify mandates expanding, I-9 audit volume increasing, and NAICS 56 (particularly 5617 and 5616) has disproportionate immigrant workforce exposure. The gap: when a manager creates a schedule, AI should automatically flag: predictive scheduling violations, overtime threshold approaches, break period compliance, credential expirations, and I-9 re-verification deadlines. AI-driven demand forecasting (predicting staffing needs from foot traffic, weather, events) can reduce overstaffing 10-15% while maintaining compliance.

models.cla_rationale: Route optimization is a mature category with strong incumbents: Descartes (acquired PC*Miler), Trimble (ALK Technologies), ORTEC, Omnitracs, Locus (last-mile optimization). However, AI-native dynamic optimization (real-time re-routing based on traffic, weather, road closures, loading dock availability) is still nascent -- most existing tools do STATIC route planning, not DYNAMIC dispatch. The AI opportunity: ingest real-time signals (traffic, weather, customer receiving hours, driver HOS remaining, fuel prices by station) and continuously re-optimize routes throughout the day. The biggest value creation is in reducing EMPTY MILES: 28% of US truck miles are driven empty (deadhead). AI matching of backhaul loads and continuous route optimization can reduce deadhead to 15-20%, saving $25-50B annually across the industry.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=logistics_optimization, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $100000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US commercial trucking: 15.5M registered vehicles. Average truck drives 100K-120K miles/year. Fuel cost at $4/gallon on 6 MPG = $67-80K/year per truck. 28% empty miles = $100B+ in wasted fuel and capacity. Current route optimization adoption: 45% of large carriers (500+ trucks) use some form, but only 12% use AI-native dynamic optimization. Small carriers (<20 trucks): <5% use route optimization software. Diesel prices volatile: $3.50-5.50/gallon range since 2022. EV trucks introduce new optimization parameters (charging station location, battery range degradation, time-of-use electricity pricing). The dual-fleet transition (ICE + EV) creates complexity that AI is uniquely positioned to manage: which truck gets which route based on range requirements, charging infrastructure, and delivery deadlines. Route optimization for EV commercial fleets is essentially a new category with no incumbents.

Moat advantage is moderate — data on placement outcomes compounds over time (which placements succeed, which fail, why), but talent marketplaces face multi-homing problem (candidates list on multiple platforms). models.deep_dive_evidence: The US staffing industry generates $290B+ annually (Staffing Industry Analysts, growing at 2.2% CAGR to 2030). The industry's structural economics are under assault: traditional staffing agencies charge 25-50% markups on hourly rates for candidate sourcing, screening, and employer-of-record services. AI-powered matching can perform sourcing and screening at near-zero marginal cost. Robert Half (RHI) stock declined 53% from peak and ManpowerGroup (MAN) declined 44% — these are the market pricing in structural disruption, not cyclical weakness. IT staffing aggregate revenue is down 9% with larger firms suffering most. The direct sourcing model allows enterprises to build their own curated talent pools, bypassing staffing agency intermediation. Beeline's acquisition of MBO Partners (June 2025) signals enterprise VMS platforms moving into direct sourcing. 65% of recruiters have already implemented AI tools (DemandSage), primarily for candidate sourcing (58% use case), time savings (44%), and cost reduction (30% per hire). The freelance platforms market is $5.6B in 2024 growing to $14.4B by 2030 (Grand View Research, 17.7% CAGR). But this understates the opportunity: the real TAM is the delta between the $200B+ staffing market and the 25-50% markup that AI eliminates — roughly $50-100B in intermediation value at risk. Even capturing 10-15% of this displacement represents a $5-15B market for AI-native staffing platforms.

models.name: Intermodal Optimization & Visibility Platform
models.one_liner: AI-powered intermodal freight optimization platform balancing truck-rail-ship modal selection for shippers in the $27.5-54B US intermodal market growing at 11.7-13.5% CAGR to $78.9-93.5B by 2030
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth

models.cla_rationale: Intermodal optimization sits between two oligopolies: Class I railroads (7 companies, 94% of freight rail revenue) and large trucking carriers. J.B. Hunt is the dominant intermodal player ($6.5B intermodal revenue, 100K+ containers). Traditional intermodal brokers/IMCs (Hub Group, STG Logistics, XPO) handle modal selection manually. The AI opportunity is DYNAMIC modal optimization: for any given shipment, should it move truck-only, rail-truck, or rail-truck-rail based on real-time pricing, capacity, transit time, carbon emissions, and weather? Current technology: most shippers use static routing rules, not dynamic optimization. The platform that can ingest live rail capacity (from all 7 Class I railroads) and truck capacity (from 500K+ carriers) and optimize in real-time wins. MO is 6 because J.B. Hunt and Hub Group have strong intermodal positions but lack AI optimization depth.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=supply_chain_optimization, buyer=enterprise, frag=6, tam_source=parsed $50000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: US intermodal volumes: 14.8M containers/trailers moved in 2024. Rail intermodal is 3.5x more fuel efficient than over-the-road trucking. EPA Scope 3 emissions reporting requirements are driving corporate shippers to track and reduce transportation emissions -- rail intermodal is the easiest way to show 40-60% CO2 reduction per shipment. Driver shortage makes intermodal structural: one train replaces 280 trucks. Class I railroad on-time performance improved to 75-85% (up from 60-70% during 2021-2022 service crisis), making intermodal viable for time-sensitive freight again. Key pain point: intermodal transit time variability. AI can predict actual transit time (not published schedule) based on rail congestion, weather, terminal dwell time -- reducing variability from +/- 2 days to +/- 0.5 days. This predictability unlocks $50B+ of freight currently moving by truck because shippers cannot accept intermodal variability.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Food safety compliance technologies market projected from $12.2B (2025) to $19.8B by 2030 (Fact.MR, 10.4% CAGR). Blockchain and traceability technologies expected to lead with 35% share. The regulatory tailwind is powerful: FDA FSMA (Food Safety Modernization Act) requires preventive controls and supply chain documentation for food service operations. The CDC estimates 48M foodborne illnesses annually in the US, resulting in 128,000 hospitalizations and 3,000 deaths — creating persistent regulatory pressure. For restaurants specifically: HACCP (Hazard Analysis Critical Control Points) compliance requires temperature logging, food handling documentation, and cleaning verification — traditionally done on paper clipboards. IoT sensors can automate temperature monitoring 24/7 (walk-in coolers, freezers, prep stations, serving lines), alerting managers before food spoilage occurs. ComplianceMate (acquired by Emerson for undisclosed) monitors 250,000+ sensors in food service. Therma (backed by Google's Area 120) raised $12.5M for refrigeration monitoring. The per-location economics: a single spoilage incident costs $2,000-10,000 in wasted food; a health department violation costs $500-5,000 in fines plus potential closure. Automated monitoring at $150-300/month prevents both. QCEW data shows food service contractors (722310, $37,468 avg pay) growing 11.6% — these institutional food operations (hospitals, schools, corporate) have the strictest compliance requirements and are the most receptive enterprise buyers.

(2) Katerra (failed 2021 after $2B raised -- cautionary tale). (3) Factory_OS, Volumetric Building Companies, MiTek -- factory-focused. (4) Autodesk and Revit offer design tools but not factory optimization. The software opportunity is the CONNECTOR: translating architectural designs into manufacturable modular units, optimizing factory scheduling, coordinating logistics (oversized loads, crane scheduling), and managing on-site assembly. Katerra's failure was vertical integration (trying to be both factory and software); the opportunity is to be the SOFTWARE LAYER for the 500+ modular factories. Demand visibility is moderate: modular is growing but still <5% of residential starts.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=vertical_saas, buyer=smb_mid, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $228900M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Global modular construction market: $91.25B (2025) to $122.24B (2030) at 6.3% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). Alternative estimates: $105.7B to $155.9B (Roots Analysis), $173.5B to $228.9B (Future Market Insights -- broader definition including prefab components). US modular: ~5% of new residential construction in 2025, projected to reach 10-15% by 2030. Key drivers: (1) Labor: modular requires 30-50% fewer on-site labor hours. (2) Speed: 30-50% faster construction time. (3) Quality: factory-controlled environment reduces defects 50-70%. (4) Cost: currently 5-15% cheaper for multifamily at scale. Barriers: (1) Transportation logistics (modules limited by highway dimensions), (2) Local building code variability (state-by-state approval), (3) Financing (lenders unfamiliar with modular workflows). Katerra's $2B failure in 2021 (tried to vertically integrate design, manufacturing, and construction) proves the danger of over-integration. The software-only play avoids this risk: serve the 500+ modular factories with design-to-factory tools, production scheduling, supply chain management, and site coordination. ICON's 3D printing ($451M raised) validates investor interest but is hardware-heavy.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Building code compliance market: $8.2B (2023) to $17.52B (2032) at 8.8% CAGR (Coherent Market Insights). 19,000+ building jurisdictions in the US, each with potentially different code amendments. Average permit review time: 4-16 weeks. First-time plan rejection rate: 30-50% (plans fail code check, must be revised and resubmitted). 1.5M+ building permits issued annually. PermitFlow ($31M+ raised) automates permit applications (filing, tracking, expediting) for contractors -- claims 75% time reduction. But the BIGGER opportunity is automated plan review: using AI to check architectural/engineering plans against building codes BEFORE submission. This is the 10x value creation because it eliminates the 4-16 week review cycle and 30-50% rejection rate. Energy code complexity is exploding: IECC 2024 requires energy modeling, blower door tests, and thermal bridging calculations that most small builders cannot perform without software assistance. 70% of firms in developed regions already rely on software for LEED compliance. Accela dominates the government permitting platform market but has not built AI plan review. The integration play: AI pre-check on contractor side + digital submission to government + automated review on government side = end-to-end digitization.

Cost per driver hire: $8-12K (recruiting + CDL training + first-month productivity loss). Annual industry turnover cost: $8.6B+. Top reasons drivers quit: (1) home time (34%), (2) compensation (28%), (3) dispatch treatment (19%), (4) equipment quality (12%). Detention time: drivers wait unpaid average 2.5 hours per pickup/delivery. AI can predict quit risk by analyzing: detention frequency, miles dispatched vs promised, home-time compliance, pay vs market rate, driver-dispatcher communication patterns. Autonomous trucks will eventually reduce need for drivers but the TRANSITION PERIOD (2026-2035) requires maximum optimization of the human workforce.

models.cla_rationale: TMS is a mature category with established enterprise players: Oracle TMS, SAP Transportation Management, Blue Yonder, Manhattan Associates, and MercuryGate. However, the MID-MARKET ($10-500M freight spend) is underserved: enterprise TMS costs $500K-5M to implement, while small shipper tools (FreightPOP, ShipStation) are too basic. Cloud-native mid-market TMS players are emerging: project44 (visibility), Turvo (TMS), Kuebix (acquired by Trimble), but no clear winner. The opportunity: build a Shopify-for-freight -- self-serve, cloud-native, AI-powered TMS that a mid-market shipper can deploy in weeks, not months. MO is 6 because the enterprise players are not competing aggressively in mid-market. MA is 6 because TMS features are well-understood and replicable, but data advantage and integration depth create differentiation over time.

models.deep_dive_evidence: TMS market: $18.5B (2025), growing to $37B (2030). Cloud segment is fastest-growing at 20%+ CAGR. 65% of mid-market shippers ($10-500M freight spend) still use spreadsheets, email, and phone for freight management. Average mid-market shipper overpays 8-15% on freight due to lack of rate optimization and carrier benchmarking. Legacy TMS implementation: 6-18 months, $500K-5M cost. Cloud-native TMS deployment: 2-6 weeks, $2-10K/month. The mid-market gap: 50K+ US companies with $10-500M in freight spend that cannot justify enterprise TMS but desperately need better visibility, rate optimization, and carrier management. AI-powered features: automated carrier selection (matching load characteristics to carrier capabilities/pricing), dynamic rate benchmarking (are you paying fair market rate?), automated invoice auditing (carriers overbill 3-5% of invoices -- $7.5B annually in overcharges industry-wide), and emissions tracking for Scope 3 reporting.

models.name: Wide-Bandgap Semiconductor Fabless Design
models.one_liner: Fabless design house specializing in SiC and GaN power semiconductor chips for EV inverters, data center power supplies, and renewable energy converters — riding the $18.4B wide-bandgap market by 2030 with design IP and OSAT partnerships
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Manufacturing — Electronics successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=33, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: Silicon carbide (SiC) and gallium nitride (GaN) power semiconductors are replacing silicon IGBTs in high-power applications due to 50% lower switching losses, 10x higher switching frequency, and higher temperature operation. The SiC power device market reached $4.1B in 2024 and is projected to hit $12.6B by 2030 (Yole, 21% CAGR). GaN power adds another $5.8B by 2030 (primarily in <900V applications: data center power supplies, phone chargers, solar microinverters). The combined wide-bandgap market of $18.4B by 2030 is being driven by three converging demands: EVs (each EV uses $300-500 of SiC in the main inverter — Tesla's Model 3/Y use STMicro SiC MOSFETs), data center power (AI GPU racks draw 40-120kW requiring high-efficiency power conversion), and renewable energy (solar inverters and wind turbine converters). The market is supply-constrained: Wolfspeed's $5B Mohawk Valley fab expansion has faced repeated delays and the company's stock has declined 80%+ since 2023. Established players (Infineon, STMicro, ON Semi, ROHM) are vertically integrated, but the fabless opportunity exists because SiC/GaN foundry capacity (from X-FAB, Tower Semiconductor, and emerging Chinese fabs) is becoming available — enabling design houses to compete without $1-5B fab investments. CHIPS Act Section 48D provides 25% investment tax credits for semiconductor manufacturing, and Department of Commerce grants target SiC/GaN specifically. The design challenge: SiC/GaN devices require fundamentally different circuit topologies, gate drivers, and thermal management — creating space for specialized design IP. Navitas Semiconductor ($NVTS, GaN focus, $120M revenue run-rate) and EPC (acquired by Renesas) validate the fabless WBG model.

models.name: Carbon Credit Verification and Registry Platform
models.one_liner: Digital-native carbon credit registry with AI-powered MRV (measurement, reporting, verification) — rebuilding trust in voluntary carbon markets after the integrity crisis by providing satellite-verified, transparent credit issuance
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=54, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: The voluntary carbon market experienced an integrity crisis in 2023-2024 when investigations (The Guardian, Bloomberg) found that major Verra-certified REDD+ forest carbon credits were largely worthless — up to 94% of offsets did not represent real emissions reductions. Market volume dropped from $2B (2023) to estimated $1.5B (2024) as corporate buyers paused purchases. This crisis creates a rebuild opportunity: the Integrity Council for the Voluntary Carbon Market (ICVCM) published Core Carbon Principles requiring enhanced additionality, permanence, and robust MRV. Article 6 of the Paris Agreement (operationalized at COP28/29) establishes a framework for international carbon trading that requires registry-level transparency. The technology to solve verification exists: satellite-based forest monitoring (Planet Labs provides 3m resolution daily global imagery), LiDAR-measured biomass estimation, and IoT-enabled soil carbon measurement can replace the site-visit-based verification that enabled fraud. Pachama (raised $79M) and Sylvera (raised $57M) provide AI-powered carbon credit rating and verification. BeZero ($50M raised) rates credit quality. But the registry layer itself — where credits are issued, tracked, and retired — remains controlled by legacy nonprofits (Verra, Gold Standard) using outdated systems. A digital-native registry with satellite-verified issuance, transparent methodology scoring, and real-time monitoring could capture 10-20% of a market projected to reach $50B by 2030 (TSVCM estimate, revised down from $100B). The CORSIA aviation offset mandate (2024+) creates guaranteed demand from airlines regardless of voluntary market sentiment.

models.name: Quantum-Safe Key Management Infrastructure
models.one_liner: Enterprise PKI infrastructure platform for NIST lattice-based cryptographic key lifecycle management — generation, distribution, rotation, and revocation of ML-KEM and ML-DSA keys across hybrid classical-quantum environments
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
Incumbent firms in Information successfully deploy equivalent AI internally
models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=platform_infrastructure, NAICS=51, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=platform_infrastructure, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: The NIST PQC standards introduce fundamentally different key sizes and performance characteristics: ML-KEM-768 public keys are 1,184 bytes versus 32 bytes for X25519, and ML-DSA-65 signatures are 3,309 bytes versus 64 bytes for Ed25519. This 30-50x increase in key/signature sizes breaks assumptions embedded in every certificate management system, HSM, TLS implementation, and API gateway. Existing PKI vendors (DigiCert, Venafi, Keyfactor) manage classical certificates but lack native PQC key lifecycle support. The enterprise PKI market is $5.2B (2024, MarketsandMarkets) growing to $12.6B by 2029. The hybrid transition period (running classical and PQC algorithms simultaneously for backward compatibility) creates extraordinary complexity — every TLS connection, code signing operation, and certificate rotation must support both algorithm families. Keyfactor's 2025 Machine Identity Report found that the average enterprise manages 256,000+ certificates with 74% experiencing certificate-related outages. Adding PQC migration multiplies this complexity. The Federal PKI (FPKI) ecosystem alone manages 380+ million certificates across civilian agencies. Financial services firms (SWIFT, major banks) are piloting PQC-ready key management for payment systems. First movers include PQShield (raised $37M), Quantinuum's Quantum Origin (QRNG-based), and evolutionQ, but no dominant platform has emerged for enterprise-grade PQC key lifecycle management.

models.name: Space Debris Tracking and Collision Avoidance
models.one_liner: AI-powered space situational awareness platform providing real-time debris tracking, conjunction analysis, and collision avoidance maneuver planning for satellite operators managing 10,000+ active satellites amid 36,000+ tracked debris objects
falsification_criteria: Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months

models.cla_rationale: Heuristic v3-14: arch=data_compounding, NAICS=54, with MO/MA differentiation and VD sector adjustment
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=data_compounding, with v3-14 CAP/VEL decoupling
models.deep_dive_evidence: The orbital debris problem is reaching a critical threshold. The US Space Surveillance Network tracks 36,500+ objects larger than 10cm, but the estimated population includes 130M+ objects larger than 1mm — any of which can damage or destroy a satellite at orbital velocities (7-8 km/s in LEO). SpaceX alone has launched 6,000+ Starlink satellites with 12,000 planned; Amazon's Kuiper, OneWeb, and Chinese constellations add thousands more. The FCC's September 2024 rule requiring satellite deorbit within 5 years of mission end (reduced from 25 years) creates a regulatory mandate for active debris management. The 18th Space Defense Squadron issues 20,000+ conjunction warnings per day but cannot provide the granular, operator-specific collision avoidance analysis that constellation operators need. This gap is the commercial opportunity. LeoLabs (raised $82M) operates a ground-based radar network providing LEO tracking. ExoAnalytic Solutions uses optical telescopes. Neither provides the integrated conjunction analysis + automated maneuver planning that operators need at mega-constellation scale. The space situational awareness market is projected at $1.8B by 2028 (Allied Market Research). Each new satellite launch increases the tracking requirement exponentially (each new object creates conjunction possibilities with every existing object). Insurance is a driver: space insurance premiums ($600M+ annual market) increasingly require demonstrated collision avoidance capability. ESA's ClearSpace-1 active debris removal mission (2026 launch) validates the seriousness of the problem. The data moat: tracking history for 10,000+ objects over years creates a propagation model that improves conjunction prediction accuracy — new entrants cannot replicate historical observation data.

Slow payments cost the construction industry $40B/year (Levelset research). Lien law complexity: 50 different state lien statutes, creating compliance nightmares. Built Technologies: unicorn valuation, ~300 lending institution partners, $135B in construction value financed since 2015. The platform automates inspection scheduling, draw approval, budget tracking, and disbursement for banks. Billd ($7.3M raised Nov 2025): focuses on giving subcontractors 120-day payment terms for materials, addressing the sub-tier cash flow crisis. Rabbet: construction loan monitoring for lenders. The contractor/sub side remains largely manual: 60%+ of subcontractors report cash flow as their #1 business challenge. models.cla_rationale: Last-mile is Amazon's territory -- they deliver 60%+ of their own packages and DSP (Delivery Service Partner) program controls 3,000+ independent delivery companies. For non-Amazon retailers, the pain is acute: FedEx/UPS costs rising 5-7% annually, gig delivery (DoorDash, Instacart) unreliable for planned delivery, and building your own fleet is capital-intensive. The orchestration opportunity is for a platform that MANAGES multi-modal last-mile (mix of own fleet, gig drivers, parcel lockers, drones, micro-fulfillment) and optimizes across modes in real-time. MO is 5 because Amazon, FedEx, and UPS are massive incumbents. But 40% of e-commerce volume flows OUTSIDE Amazon and those retailers desperately need better last-mile solutions.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Last mile = 53% of total shipping cost, averaging $10.10 per last-mile delivery in the US. Amazon's DSP program: 3,000+ independent delivery companies, 275K+ drivers. FedEx/UPS parcel rates rising 5-7% annually compounding. Failed deliveries cost US retailers $17.2B annually. Consumer expectation shift: 65% expect same-day or next-day delivery (up from 36% in 2020). Micro-fulfillment centers growing 25%+ CAGR -- DoorDash DashMart, Gopuff, Getir model proving urban dark store economics. Drone delivery approved BVLOS in 4 states, with Zipline, Wing (Alphabet), and Amazon Prime Air expanding commercial operations. Autonomous delivery robots (Nuro, Serve Robotics, Starship) now in 25+ US cities. The orchestration layer -- deciding WHICH mode to use for WHICH delivery based on real-time cost/speed tradeoffs -- is the untapped software opportunity.

models.cla_rationale: Market Openness is moderate (5): Oracle Hospitality (legacy MICROS) still dominates large/chain properties but is losing share to cloud challengers. Mews, Cloudbeds, and Guesty have raised $400M+ combined and are growing rapidly. However, 61K hotel/motel establishments means the market supports multiple winners — no single cloud PMS has >10% share of independents yet. Moat Advantage is strong (7): PMS is the operational nervous system of a hotel — managing reservations, check-in/out, housekeeping, billing, channel management. Once embedded, switching is extremely painful (3-6 month migration, staff retraining, reservation data risk). Value Density is strong (7): $300-1,500/month per property depending on room count — hotels are higher-ARPU customers than restaurants. Demand Visibility is strong (8): cloud PMS adoption is at ~61% and accelerating — the remaining 39% on legacy systems represent forced migration demand.

models.deep_dive_evidence: Hotel PMS market growing from $7.91B (2024) to $14.71B by 2030 at 10.84% CAGR. Cloud segment holds 61.2% market share and growing. QCEW: 721110 (Hotels and Motels) has 61,273 establishments employing 1.515M workers at $784/week ($40,778 annual), with 6.7% employment growth YoY — the strongest recovery signal in accommodation. Oracle MICROS has been the hotel technology standard for 30+ years but its on-premise architecture is increasingly uncompetitive against cloud-native systems. Mews raised a $110M Series D (2024) at a reported $1.2B valuation; Cloudbeds raised $150M (2023); Guesty raised $170M for vacation rental PMS. The AI opportunity in PMS: automated guest communication (pre-arrival upsells, chatbot concierge, review response generation), predictive housekeeping scheduling, intelligent room assignment (maximizing loyalty member preferences), and integrated revenue management. Hilton's 'Connected Room' initiative and Marriott's AI concierge show chain demand for intelligent property systems. For independent properties, the cloud PMS becomes the platform through which all other hotel tech integrates — channel management, revenue management, guest experience, payment processing. The platform play is real: Mews has an open API marketplace with 600+ integrations.

AI in tourism projected to $13.87B by 2030 at 26.7% CAGR (Grand View Research). The guest experience AI opportunity spans the full journey: (1) Pre-arrival: automated confirmation, upsell offers (room upgrades, dining reservations, spa bookings), preference collection. (2) In-stay: AI concierge (via text/WhatsApp/in-room tablet), automated service requests (housekeeping, maintenance, amenities), real-time sentiment detection. QCEW: 721110 has 61,273 establishments. Average hotel has 24.7 workers, suggesting an average of ~80-100 rooms. The labor impact: front desk staff at hotels spend 60-70% of time on routine inquiries that AI can handle. A 100-room hotel can reduce front desk from 5 FTEs to 3 FTEs while improving guest satisfaction through 24/7 AI availability.

models.name: AI Security Threat Intelligence & Access Control Platform
models.one_liner: Converged physical-cyber security platform unifying access control, threat detection, identity management, and incident response — targeting $48.9B security analytics market by 2030
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth
Customer acquisition cost exceeds 18-month payback period in target segment

Foundation model capabilities plateau or inference costs stop declining for 18+ months
models.cla_rationale: Market openness moderate — Verkada ($4.5B) does physical security, CrowdStrike/Palo Alto/SentinelOne do cybersecurity. The convergence gap (unified physical + cyber) is underserved. Major access control players (HID Global, LenelS2, Genetec) focus on hardware. Moat advantage high: security data from physical (cameras, badges, sensors) and cyber (network logs, identity events) creates a unified threat model that single-domain vendors can't replicate. Value density very high: enterprise security budgets $500K-10M+ annually. Demand visibility strong: insider threat, workplace violence, and regulatory compliance drive converged security adoption.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=cybersecurity, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $309600M
models.deep_dive_evidence: The security analytics market stands at $19.4B in 2025 and is projected to reach $48.9B by 2030 at 20.3% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). The broader AI cybersecurity solutions market is $30.9B in 2025 growing to $86.3B by 2030 at 22.8% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). AI-based security operations reached $28.2B in 2024 and is projected to reach $82.5B by 2030 at 19.2% CAGR (NextMSC). The structural shift in NAICS 5616 is physical-cyber convergence: traditionally, physical security (guards, cameras, access control) and cybersecurity (firewalls, endpoint protection, SIEM) operated as separate silos with separate budgets, vendors, and teams. AI enables convergence because threat detection patterns span both domains — a disgruntled employee shows behavioral changes in both physical (unusual building access patterns) and digital (unusual data access patterns) domains. 73% of security leaders report needing unified physical-cyber monitoring (SIA Security Megatrends). Verkada pioneered cloud-native physical security ($4.5B valuation, 20K+ customers) but remains physical-only. CrowdStrike ($3B+ revenue) dominates endpoint cybersecurity but has no physical security capability. The convergence gap is structural: who owns the unified security operating system? Key use cases: (1) Insider threat detection: correlate badge access + network activity + communication patterns. (2) Identity-first security: unified identity across physical access (badge) and digital access (SSO/MFA). (3) Compliance: SOX, HIPAA, and FedRAMP require both physical and logical access controls documented in unified audit trails. Enterprise security spending: physical security $149.2B globally by 2030, cyber security $309.6B globally by 2030 — converged spend is a greenfield category.

models.name: AI Background Screening & Continuous Monitoring Platform

falsification_criteria: Regulatory environment simplifies, reducing demand for automated compliance

models.cla_rationale: Market openness moderate — Sterling Check (acquired by First Advantage for $2.2B, 2024), HireRight, Checkr, and GoodHire are established players. Checkr raised $679M+ and processes 5M+ background checks annually. But the shift from point-in-time pre-hire checks to continuous post-hire monitoring creates a new market that incumbents are slow to enter. Moat advantage high because verification data networks compound (every verification adds to the graph of verified credentials, employment histories, and educational records). Value density high: enterprise background screening contracts $50-500K annually, continuous monitoring 2-3x larger than point-in-time checks. Demand visibility strong: every employer screens, regulatory requirements expanding (gig economy worker verification, ban-the-box compliance).
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=compliance_automation, buyer=mid_enterprise, frag=8, tam_source=parsed $25900M
models.deep_dive_evidence: The global background screening market is valued at $14.7B in 2025 and projected to reach $25.9B by 2030 at 12.0% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). North America holds 44% market share ($6.5B in 2025). The background check software segment specifically is $4.7B growing to $7.1B by 2030 at 8.7% CAGR (Mordor Intelligence). 43% of screening vendors introduced AI-based modules between 2023-2025, improving verification speeds by 48% (Mordor Intelligence). 41% of organizations now use AI-powered systems for employment verification and criminal record tracking. The market is shifting from point-in-time pre-hire screening (80% of current revenue) to continuous post-hire monitoring (growing from <5% to projected 25-30% of revenue by 2030). This shift is driven by: (1) gig economy expansion requiring ongoing worker verification, (2) increasing regulatory requirements for continuous monitoring in financial services, healthcare, and education, (3) enterprise risk management extending beyond hire date. Key market dynamics: First Advantage acquired Sterling Check for $2.2B in 2024, consolidating the top 2 traditional players. Checkr (VC-backed, $5M+ background checks annually) targets the gig economy with API-first approach. Cross-border hiring expansion (remote work normalization) increases complexity — multilingual verification engines and international criminal record access are emerging requirements. The NAICS 5616 sub-sector that includes investigation services employs 1.1M workers. Within this, background screening is a $6.5B US sub-market currently growing at 12% CAGR, driven by tighter regulations, cross-border hiring, and the shift to continuous monitoring.

models.name: Construction Materials Procurement & Supply Chain AI
models.one_liner: AI-powered materials procurement platform with real-time pricing, demand forecasting, and supply chain visibility for the $1.5B construction procurement software market growing to $2.6B by 2032 -- reducing material cost overruns that average 10-15% of project budgets
falsification_criteria: Horizontal platform (Salesforce/Microsoft/Google) adds vertical-specific AI features matching specialist depth

models.cla_rationale: Existing players include HCSS (heavy civil focused), BIM 360 (Autodesk, design-integrated), Procore (PM-integrated procurement), and general procurement platforms (Coupa, SAP Ariba) that serve construction poorly. Construction-specific AI procurement startups include StructionSite, Kojo ($51M raised, materials procurement for electrical contractors), and Voyage Control. Kojo has validated the niche approach (starting with electrical materials). The market is moderately open because construction procurement is uniquely complex: project-based (not recurring), geographically variable, subject to long lead times, and requires integration with project schedules. Value density is moderate -- savings of 5-15% on materials (which are 40-60% of project cost) create clear ROI. Moat from pricing data accumulation across thousands of projects.
models.vcr_rationale: Fundamental v2: arch=supply_chain_optimization, buyer=enterprise, frag=10, tam_source=parsed $2100000M
models.deep_dive_evidence: Construction materials represent 40-60% of project costs ($840B-$1.26T of $2.1T US construction spending). Material cost overruns average 10-15% per project (McKinsey). Lumber price volatility: 2021 peak $1,700/MBF, 2023 low $350/MBF, 2025 ranging $450-$650/MBF. Steel: 25% tariff adds $200-400/ton. Concrete: up 30% since 2020. Construction procurement software market: $1.5B (2025) to $2.6B (2032) at 8.1% CAGR (GM Insights). Kojo ($51M raised, Series B 2023) proved the vertical approach by focusing on electrical contractor materials procurement -- claims 10-15% cost savings, 90%+ procurement digitization for customers. The broader opportunity is an AI platform that: (1) aggregates pricing across suppliers for real-time comparison, (2) forecasts material price movements using commodity futures, tariff signals, and demand indicators, (3) optimizes order timing and quantities based on project schedules and storage constraints, (4) provides supply chain visibility (lead time tracking, alternative sourcing). At $2.1T in total construction spending and 40-60% materials share, even 1% efficiency improvement = $8-12B in value created.

Climate/ESG regulation mandates create new demand vectors.
